question:

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 1)

Correct Answer:will get

Other Sentences:

    This is in the simple past tense.

  • They would have watched TV all evening.
    This is in the conditional perfect tense.

  • "would be able to be qualifying" → Incorrect and unnecessarily complex; incorrect usage.

Therefore, the improved sentence is:

question:
Select the option that corrects the following sentence.
He has broken his leg yesterday.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 2))
option_1: He broke his leg yesterday.
option_2: He has broke his leg yesterday.
option_3: He have broken his leg yesterday.
option_4: He had broke his leg yesterday.
solution:
The correct option to fix the sentence is "He broke his leg yesterday."

Explanation:

  • The sentence is referring to a past event ("yesterday"), so the simple past tense should be used instead of the present perfect tense.

  • "He has broken his leg yesterday" is incorrect because the present perfect tense ("has broken") is not typically used with specific time expressions like "yesterday."

The other options:

  • "He has broke his leg yesterday" is incorrect because "has" requires the past participle form ("broken"), not the simple past ("broke").

  • "He have broken his leg yesterday" is incorrect because "have" should be "has" when the subject is "he."

  • "He had broke his leg yesterday" is incorrect because "had broke" is the past perfect tense, which is not necessary in this context.

Thus, the correct answer is: "He broke his leg yesterday."
